Our Dairy

We Start with the Best in Texas (actually the world)!

All of our ice creams are made with 100% milk and cream from Mill-King Market & Creamery, located in McGregor, Texas, just outside of Waco. The Miller family has owned and operated this dairy for three generations. They are some of the hardest working people you will ever meet, and they truly care about the milk and cream their select herd of 100 cows produces.   The herd consists of handpicked Jersey, Brown Swiss and Holstein cows that are never given hormones or antibiotics and are primarily grass-fed. When necessary, they supplement with grain that is non-GMO, corn and soy free. The delicious milk and cream produced is always non-homogenized and low temperature pasteurized.  This essentially means any harmful bacteria is eliminated while all of the beneficial enzymes stay in tact. All of these components make for very healthy and very delicious milk and cream. This is the stuff our grandparents drank and it’s the reason we can make ice creams as honest as the ones they enjoyed.

post_title: Lick Honest Ice Creams in the News

post_content:
Our Farmers & Artisans

We Couldn't and Wouldn't do it Without Them!

Austin is blessed with numerous farms and food artisans that work with Lick Ice Creams. From the fresh mint and earthy beets we get in East Austin, to the fragrant lavender and luscious peaches harvested in the Texas Hill Country out west, we base our flavors on what the land has to offer us and when the season is right for each ingredient. We are also able to collaborate with amazing local food artisans, such as chocolatiers, bee keepers — and even butchers — who help enhance the quality and flavor profiles of our ice creams. They ensure that you’ll never find a mass-produced, generic marshmallow or a non-local hint of honey in any of our ice creams.   Johnsons Backyard Garden Hausbar Farm Boggy Creek Farm Springdale Farm Lightsey Farms Pure Luck Farm & Dairy G & S Groves Great Bean Chocolate Delysia Chocolatier Salt & Time Austin Honey Company Pecan Street Rum Garrison Brothers Bourbon Texas Olive Ranch Princess & Moose's Sister Bakery Genius Gin

There really is a Hazel and she’s my granny.  Each year for Thanksgiving she would make at least one pumpkin pie and she’d say it was just for me, usually by whispering it in my ear.  Maybe she didn’t want the other grandchildren to hear.  Whatever the reason, I LOVE her pumpkin pie.  I remember seeing them lined up with the other desserts on my grandparents’ bar and going out of my mind counting the minutes until it was time to dive in.  I’m a huge baked goods fanatic and even among all the other offerings my family members had crafted, my main objective was to get a piece of her pumpkin pie on my plate before it had been devoured by my cousins. So what made Hazel’s pumpkin pie leave such an impression on me, even after all these years?  Sure, you could assume that it was just the fact that my Granny, one of the women who taught me to bake and a person I love with all my heart, made the cake and I would of course love it out of my sheer emotional connection to the baker.   That is not the case.  Her pies really focused on the pumpkin.  So many times a pumpkin pie is loaded up with spices that the subtle, fresh flavor of the pumpkin is lost and it ends up tasting like a cinnamon pie with a dash of clove, nutmeg and ginger.  Granny’s pies were simple and delicious.  There was a nice balance of nutmeg, ginger and cinnamon.  She went a bit heavier on the clove, which I love.  I also remember eating her pumpkin pie and not feeling the need to cover it in whipped cream, although I have to admit (and I say this knowing I may be a bit judged) that there were times that I added a hefty dollop of cool-whip.   Today, we pay homage to this lovely, feisty, Texas lady with the flavor Hazel’s Pumpkin Pie.  We buy Texas pie pumpkins and roast them in the oven in our very own kitchen.  Once the seeds and flesh have been removed, pounds of it are blended into our ice cream base and enhanced with a little nutmeg, ginger and cinnamon.  We go a bit heavy on the clove.  What we get is the best pumpkin ice cream I’ve ever had that tastes like the most delicious, freshest pumpkin pie I’ve ever eaten.  Actually, if you’ve never had the pleasure of eating my Granny’s pumpkin pie, it’s probably better.

NEW! Apple Cheddar Shortie

Homemade rosemary cheddar cookies made with Texas' own Veldehuizen Cheddar and Pure Luck rosemary are crumbled into our sweet Sonlight Orchard apple ice cream.

Each day we are lucky enough to go to work at a place where we can explore new flavors, meet new people and be inspired by the state we live in.  Here at Lick Honest Ice Creams, we celebrate the farmers, produce, artisans and Texas nostalgia that surround us through the ice creams we create.   I’ve always been in love with both Texas and ice cream.  Growing up in Hallettsville, a small town settled by German and Czech immigrants, I had the great fortune of living in a community that appreciated and practiced the art of growing and crafting things in an honest way.   My grandparents had a farm and I relished walking in the fields and pastures with my family.  We’d walk in the shade and pick delicious, buttery Texas pecans, shelling and eating them as we took in the breeze.  I was always so impressed and proud to see my grandma selling her fresh produce at the farmers market on our town square.  This sense of pride I saw in my grandparents is what we all feel here toward our ice creams. Every summer, which can extend from March to October, I made ice cream with my family.  We would of course make the standards but we also delighted in making flavors that featured the local bounty.  Pecan, peach and dewberry were my personal favorites.  We’d sit in the shade, one of us usually planted atop the ice cream maker, and one cranking away on the handle.   Now, we get to make ice cream like this (with the exception of the hand crank) everyday of the year.  From the local grass-fed milk and cream to the produce, chocolate and honey brought to us by the most amazing, down to earth farmers and artisans, we’re continually inspired. I share all of this as a way to convey just how connected I and all of us who work at Lick Honest Ice Creams feel to the ice creams we craft.  We get to make something we’re so proud of and head over heels in love with every day.  Thanks to all of our supporters for helping us do what we love to do.  We hope you love it too!

Inspired by the Mexican beverage, this milky sweet rice ice cream is flavored with cinnamon, vanilla, and a touch of clove.

Texas apples are impressive.

Anthony and I bounced an idea for apple ice cream around for months, maybe even years.  I was admittedly the potential flavor’s antagonist – having grown up an apple snob in the northeast, I was nothing short of skeptical of Texas apples.  Anthony told me stories of going to orchards in the summer to pick apples.  In 100 degree weather?  When it’s too hot to ever rain?  When the grass turns to hay?  No way.  That sounds to me like a recipe for soft, mealy, ferment-y apples.  Cider apples.  Sauce apples.

Let me tell you, I was so, so wrong.

After living in Texas for 2 years, it was time to get over my Texas apple suspicion.  I’m putting it lightly when I say that Anthony was VERY excited.

We got really lucky this year.  Our first contact was Don Durflinger from a very quaint pick-your-own orchard in Mason, TX called Sonlight Orchard.  Don and his wife Sheila proudly own and run the orchard themselves.  Once I got a hold of Don, we spoke on the phone for about an hour sharing apple facts and stories.  I told him about all of the varieties of apples I ate right off of the tree in New York.  He told me how the apples in Texas are different from those that I described because his apples are sweeter, denser, greener, and absolutely delicious.  He told me that he does not retail or wholesale his apples because he wants for there to always be enough apples for the weekend pickers.  Don is proud of his orchard.  He loves his apples and loves watching people pick his apples.

Despite everything Don told me, up until the moment that Anthony and I walked up to the Sonlight Orchard barn and were almost immediately handed chunks of apples to taste from Don & Sheila’s hands, I was skeptical.  Then I tasted his Red Delicious, then Cameo, and finally Fuji.   Each was uniquely delicious.  Little apples with green and red skins and dense, crisp, and juicy flesh.  They were the most unique and most admirable little apples.  I love these apples too.

Back in our kitchen, with the apples that me, Anthony, Don, and Sheila picked, we made the ultimate apple cheddar ice cream.

Sweetened with a touch of honey and sugar (the apples are so sweet they barely need any sugar!), chunks of Don’s apples were baked until barely soft and simply blended into our ice cream base. Then, with some help from Henri’s Cheese, we found an awesome cheddar from Veldhuizen Cheese in Dublin, Texas, and turned it into a crunchy, cheesy, salty rosemary cheddar cracker.  It’s everything that reminds us of fall and we love it.  We love Texas apples (myself included)!

We only have a limited quantity of Don’s apples, so grab a scoop or pint of this flavor before they run out!

post_title: Ice Cream Is Better When It's Cold
Why Love Ice Cream In The Winter

post_content:
It's a mess outside, guys!  It's gloomy, 50 degrees, and raining as I write, hiding in a windowless room, eating countless spoonfuls of ice cream.  Good news for y'all is that it's probably 70 degrees and sunny as you read this.  (It is, right?!)
This is Texas in November, folks.  There are cold fronts, rain, and sometimes (rarely) ice, but if you give it a couple of days, the sun always returns to warm us back up.  That's why I fled the Northeast as soon as I could.  I outright cannot tolerate cold... except for cold ice cream.
It's a little bit ironic, but I love ice cream MOST in the winter.
Ice cream serves a very special purpose in the winter.  It's an indulgent, belly-warming, sweet, and satisfying treat for the end of every dark winter day.  It's the best feel-good food.  Straight out of a pint with a really big spoon, scooped onto a warm slice of pecan pie, or floating in a tall glass of dark beer, ice cream seems to round out every dish, every meal, every day.
I crave warm, rich foods & drinks in cold weather.  If you do too, then you definitely want some of these this season.  With a scoop of ice cream.  Or you might just find yourself savoring your ice cream straight out of the pint for hours because it takes so much longer to melt in the cold.  I've already had this pint on my desk for forty five minutes and it's still solid ... as if there aren't already enough reasons to love wintertime ice cream.
post_title: Ice Cream Is Better When It's Cold

It's a mess outside, guys!  It's gloomy, 50 degrees, and raining as I write, hiding in a windowless room, eating countless spoonfuls of ice cream.  Good news for y'all is that it's probably 70 degrees and sunny as you read this.  Or if it isn't, it probably will be in a couple of days.

I crave warm, rich foods & drinks in cold weather.  Pie, cobbler, brownies, coffee, tea, hot chocolate.  With ice cream.  Have you ever had a scoop of vanilla ice cream in your coffee?  It's better than any coffee creamer.  In hot chocolate, it's better than marshmallows.  With a pint readily available in the freezer, you might find yourself savoring your ice cream straight out of the pint for hours because it takes so much longer to melt in the cold.  I've been nursing this still-frozen pint on my desk for an hour ... as if there aren't already enough reasons to love ice cream in this weather.
- Diana Vassar, Kitchen Manager

I crave warm, rich foods & drinks in cold weather.  Pie, cobbler, brownies, coffee, tea, hot chocolate.  With ice cream.  Have you ever had a scoop of vanilla ice cream in your coffee?  It's better than any coffee creamer.  In hot chocolate, it's better than marshmallows.  With a pint readily available in the freezer, you might find yourself savoring your ice cream straight out of the pint for hours because it takes so much longer to melt in the cold.  I've been nursing this still-frozen pint on my desk for an hour ... as if there aren't already enough reasons to love ice cream in this weather.
- Diana Vassar, Kitchen Manager
post_title: Ice Cream Is Better When It's Cold

post_content:
It's a mess outside, guys!  It's gloomy, 50 degrees, and raining as I write, hiding in a windowless room, eating countless spoonfuls of ice cream.  Good news for y'all is that it's probably 70 degrees and sunny as you read this.  Or if it isn't, it probably will be in a couple of days. This is Texas in November, folks.  There are cold fronts, rain, and sometimes (rarely) ice, but if you give it a couple of days, the sun always returns to warm you back up.  That's why I fled the Northeast as soon as I could.  I outright cannot tolerate cold... except for cold ice cream.   It's a little bit ironic, but I love ice cream MOST in the winter.  
  Ice cream serves a very special purpose in the winter.  It's an indulgent, belly-warming, sweet, and satisfying treat for the end of every dark winter day.  It's the best feel-good food.  Straight out of a pint with a really big spoon, scooped onto a warm slice of pecan pie, or floating in a tall glass of dark beer, ice cream seems to round out every dish, every meal, every day.   I crave warm, rich foods & drinks in cold weather.  Pie, cobbler, brownies, coffee, tea, hot chocolate.  With ice cream.  Have you ever had a scoop of vanilla ice cream in your coffee?  It's better than any coffee creamer.  In hot chocolate, it's better than marshmallows.  With a pint readily available in the freezer, you might find yourself savoring your ice cream straight out of the pint for hours because it takes so much longer to melt in the cold.  I've been nursing this still-frozen pint on my desk for an hour ... as if there aren't already enough reasons to love ice cream in this weather.
- Diana Vassar, Kitchen Manager

NEW! Horchata

Inspired by the Mexican beverage, this milky sweet rice ice cream is flavored with cinnamon, vanilla, and a touch of clove.

S'more Meringue

For this summertime classic, we replace marshmallow with a torched homemade meringue that's folded into a Round Rock Honey. molasses and cinnamon graham cracker flavored base. Bits of Great Bean Chocolate top off this melty s'more treat!

Persimmons & Sage

The sweet, delicate taste of locally grown persimmons gets a kick from robust sage!

Orange Chocolate

Fresh, organic Texas oranges are combined with local Great Bean chocolate.

Candied Pecan & Bourbon

Pecans baked with brown sugar, cardamom and thyme are blended with Garrison Brothers Texas Bourbon.

Spiked Eggnog

A holiday favorite! Homemade eggnog prepared with Vital Farms pasture raised, organic eggs and a shot of Brandy.

Peppermint Bark

Inspired by the season, fresh peppermint and sweet cream are accented with a swirl of Great Bean chocolate ganache.

Hazel's Pumpkin Pie

Roasted, locally grown pie pumpkins are enhanced by cinnamon, a bit of clove and nutmeg. Just like Granny Hazel makes it!

Sweet Potato

Hints of ground nutmeg, molasses and local Austin Honey Company honey bring out the best in the deliciously ambrosial roasted sweet potatoes.

Chocolate Coconut Cream Pie

With a little bit of cinnamon and a thick swirl of sweet shredded coconut custard, it tastes just like the pie your Grandma would make!

Vegan Vanilla Pear (vegan)

Our smooth and creamy coconut milk base is accented with Madagascar Bourbon Vanilla and a swirl of our fresh, house made vanilla pear butter!

Coconut Chia Chai

Crunchy chia seeds speckle our spiced coconut chai tea ice cream made with The Steeping Room’s Kashmiri chai tea blend.

post_title: This Pint Was Packed By Hand

post_content: asdjahskjdhas
asdjahskjdhas

Our kitchen staff is awesome.  Although we’re forever growing – soon to open new shops and add our ice cream to the shelves of more grocery stores both big and small around the state – there are just a few skilled hands working every day to make our ice cream.  They put the stickers on every pint, hand write the flavors on every pint lid, bake every cake and component from scratch, chop every bunch of herbs,  swirl every sauce into each tub of ice cream, and hand pack every pint.  They work really hard to make sure that the ice cream y’all enjoy is as good as it can possibly be.

Emily leads the churning team.  She grew up in Austin, spent a few years in NYC, and (lucky for us) began working at Lick shortly after her return to Texas.  In Austin and in New York, Emily gained years of experience cooking great food for well respected restaurants, cafes, and catering companies.  She’s an exceptionally talented cook.  There’s a good chance that Emily inspired the delicious new flavor that we recently introduced and an even better chance that she churned it.  In all seriousness, Emily makes the most beautiful swirls we’ve ever seen.

Claire started at Lick writing lids and quickly took over all of our ice cream prep work.  After graduating from pastry school in Colorado, she moved to Austin to pursue chocolate.  She loves chocolate.  She makes the prettiest molded chocolates and sometimes brings them to work to share with the sweet fiends in the office.  (Thank you, Claire!)  We’re so lucky that Claire also loves ice cream because she’s really good at making it.  The beautifully executed cakes, luscious curds, sauces, and every one of our components are all thanks to her.

Alyssa is a pastry school graduate, native Austinite, and newest addition to our team.  She came to us after a few months of high altitude baking in the mountains of Colorado.  She’s an avid baker and, unlike many, quickly mastered packing ice cream into a pint – it truly is so much harder than it looks!  She clearly knows how to wield a spatula.  And of all of us in the kitchen, Alyssa treats us to more homemade desserts than the rest of us combined.  (Did I mention that we like sweets?)

NEW! Gingerbread Scotch Ale

Our house made spiced gingerbread is folded into a Guadalupe Brewing Company Scotch Ale flavored ice cream.

Brown Butter Brown Sugar

Speckled with flecks of browned butter and sweetened with a scoop of brown sugar, this rich flavor is perfect on its own or paired with nearly anything!

Grapefruit with Champagne Marshmallows

Our friends at Princess & Moose's Sister Bakery have created for us, handmade champagne marshmallows (corn syrup free, of course) that  we  float through a refreshing and tart grapefruit ice cream.  Grapefruits are from the good ole' Rio Grande Valley!

Tart Toasted Coconut

Sweet and nutty toasted coconut flakes with tart lemon-lime curd, courtesy of the Rio Grande Valley.  Tastes like a key lime coconut cream pie!   (Note, this flavor is not vegan as it contains eggs)

NEW! Orange Coconut Marmalade

House made orange marmalade is swirled into our orange blossom and vanilla bean flavored coconut ice cream in this vegan holiday flavor.

Orange Chocolate

Fresh, organic Texas oranges are combined with local Great Bean chocolate.

Candied Pecan & Bourbon

Pecans baked with brown sugar, cardamom and thyme are blended with Garrison Brothers Texas Bourbon.

Spiked Eggnog

A holiday favorite! Homemade eggnog prepared with Vital Farms pasture raised, organic eggs and a shot of Brandy.

Peppermint Bark

Inspired by the season, fresh peppermint and sweet cream are accented with a swirl of Great Bean chocolate ganache.

NEW! Coconut Chia Chai

Crunchy chia seeds speckle our spiced coconut chai tea ice cream made with The Steeping Room’s Kashmiri chai tea blend.

NEW! Chocolate Peanut Butter Brownie

Our Great Bean Chocolate ice cream blends beautifully with creamy peanut butter and big chunks of decadent brownie.

Frequently Asked Questions

Get Honest Answers About Honest Ice Creams

Is your ice cream organic?

No. Although we use as many organic ingredients as possible, not everything we use is certified organic; and, therefore we cannot label Lick ice creams as “organic.” Since we cannot source everything organic, we make every effort to get our ingredients from sustainable farmers and responsible artisans; luckily, in Austin, Texas, they’re not too hard to find!

Are your products gluten-free?

Yes. Our ice creams are gluten-free. If there are ever any exceptions to this, we will certainly make it known to our customers. Our homemade ice cream cones are NOT gluten-free.

Are your waffle cones homemade?

Yes. We make our cone mix from scratch and roll each one by hand in our South Austin shop. Our cones contain local organic eggs and are NOT gluten-free.

Where do you make your ice cream?

We make every single batch by hand at our production kitchen in Northwest Austin.  Each flavor is created in 2½ gallon batches and either sent by the tub to our South Lamar shop or packed by hand into pint containers and distributed to our many wholesale customers in the Austin area.

Are all of your ingredients locally sourced?

Locavorism is very important to Lick Ice Creams, and we source locally every chance we get. Unfortunately, ingredients like vanilla, cocoa, coconut milk, and a handful of others do not yet grow in Texas. If ingredients are not available to be locally sourced, we make it a point to acquire them from small, locally-owned businesses wherever possible.
